item.title: [DERBY-3420] The -ca option should be removed from ij and from the ij command usage line
item.description:
The ij tool gives the following help output:

Usage: java org.apache.derby.tools.ij [-p propertyfile] [-ca connectionAttributePropertyFile] [inputfile]

The -ca connectionAttributePropertyFile option is no longer needed and is deprecated, so it is not documented in the Tools Guide. The option should also be removed from the usage statement.
item.summary: The -ca option should be removed from ij and from the ij command usage line

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: If this is a feature that will not and should not be used, nor documented, wouldn't it be appropriate to also remove the code implementing it?
If it is actually implemented in Derby, then yes, I think the code should be removed too.

This seems like a small, isolated change request that's been
languishing for some time, so I thought I'd see if I could take
care of it. Attached 'removeObsoleteArg.diff' patch proposal does
the following:

  • removes the -ca argument from the usage message
  • removes the support for -ca from the IJ code
  • updates the ij usage test

Regression testing (and a bit of ad-hoc testing) was clean.

Comments and suggestions are most welcome.

I'm not sure I see why this has to be removed. The issue description says that it's no longer needed, but it doesn't say which alternatives the users have or why it's bad to have alternatives. I'm not saying that we shouldn't remove the option, just that I don't fully understand why it should be removed.

If we remove the code, I guess we should also remove the connAttributeDefaults variable/parameter from ij.Main.mainCore(), ij.Main.go() and ij.utilMain.go() (it's always null now). I think the utilMain.connAttributeDefaults variable is also always null, so it can be removed too, together with utilMain.getConnectionAttributeDefaults(). Same goes for this section in ij.jj:

// If no ATTRIBUTES on the connection get them from the
// defaults
if (connInfo == null)
connInfo = util.updateConnInfo(userS,passwordS,
utilInstance.getConnAttributeDefaults());
else
connInfo = util.updateConnInfo(userS,passwordS, connInfo);

which can be replaced with

connInfo = util.updateConnInfo(userS, passwordS, connInfo);

Thanks Knut for catching that I had only partially removed the implementation.

I suppose another alternative would be to remove the reference from the usage
message (and the test output), but leave the -ca implementation in place.

I'm a little concerned about the utility of a feature for which (apparently) the
community has written neither documentation nor tests. By proposing to
remove the implementation, I was agreeing with John's observation that if
we don't wish to document and test the feature, why do we want to keep the code?
We could always recover the code later from the svn history if we changed our mind.

I think at this point I find that I don't understand what purpose the feature has, but
on the other hand am quite happy to leave the feature if the community feels it
might be useful.

But if we decide to leave it, it seems like we ought to be able to come up with
enough of an example of how to use it, that we could turn that example into
a test and some documentation.

Kim, when you originally reported this issue, you wrote that the -ca option
was "no longer needed and is deprecated"; do you recall what discussions led
to that conclusion?

Here's an example of how to use it:

1) Create a file called connection.properties which contains:

territory=no_NO
collation=TERRITORY_BASED
create=true

2) Start ij with -ca connection.properties

Now databases that don't exist should be automatically created when you connect to them, and they should have Norwegian collation by default.

3) Connect to a database that doesn't already exist and see that it's created and that ORDER BY uses Norwegian collation rules:

ij> connect 'jdbc:derby:mydb';
ij> select * from (values 'aa','ab','ba','bb') v order by x;
X
–
ab
ba
bb
aa

4 rows selected

DERBY-3105 contains the discussion which led to the
conclusion that the -ca argument should be removed.

After re-reading Kathey's comments in DERBY-3105, I'm tempted to leave the
-ca implementation present, and just remove it from the usage message. That way
the option will still work, if somebody is somehow depending on it from back in
the Cloudscape days, but it won't confuse new users who encounter the usage message.

If we remove all traces of it in the documentation and the usage message, it'll eventually end up as dead code that no one understands the purpose of anyway. If we think that users should use another mechanism, and that the -ca option is barely used (probably true since it's not documented), would it be a cleaner solution to remove both the code and the usage message and add a release note telling users what they should do instead?

Attached is 'removeMoreCodeReferences.diff', which chases down
the rest of the -ca processing in the IJ code and removes it.

Regression tests were clean; comments and suggestions are most welcome.
I didn't find anything more to remove, so +1 from me to commit the patch and add a release note telling the option is gone.

Thanks Bryan, the release note is very clear and well written. (Tiny nits: mixed use of ij/IJ and url/URL, and the connection URL contains a superfluous semicolon at the end.) Verified that org.apache.derbyBuild.ReleaseNoteReader accepts the note.

Minor changes to releaseNode.html to spell 'ij' consistently in lower-case,
'URL' consistently in upper case, and to remove the stray semi-colon.

I'm intending to commit this patch to the trunk in the next few days.

I'm afraid there's still one little problem. You did right to remove the colon from within the single quote, but the punctuation mark at the end should be a semicolon:

connect 'jdbc:derby:myDB;territory=no_NO;collation=TERRITORY_BASED;create=true';

Thanks!

Committed to the trunk as revision 737948. Marked the issue as resolved,
since it doesn't seem worth porting this change back to earlier branches.
Closing, after checking that option no longer appears in usage statement and that trying to use it results in the correct usage statement.
